overview: The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [11] It also establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [11] The judiciary is required to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [11]
appropriations: The Committee has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts to facilitate further discussion on the measure. [12] The Department of Health requests a budget of $221,788 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) to support the Kona division pilot project. [10] This request includes $145,000 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Clinical Psychologist and $76,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Social Worker or Human Services professional. [12]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's cost estimate for a three-year pilot project would be $514,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026, $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027, and $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2027-2028. [10] The proposal calls for the Kona Women’s Court program to be supervised by the Kona Division of Big Island Drug Court, which will leverage existing BIDC structure and staff. [10] The Department of Health's request for $221,788 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) is based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [10]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program, under the supervision of the big island drug court. [11] The Department of Health’s role has been to provide screening and assessments of possible eligible participants for the program, including forensic mental health consultation and coordination. [10] The Department of Health requests a 1.0 FTE Clinical Psychologist at a cost of $145,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) and a 1.0 FTE Social Worker/Human Services Professional IV at a cost of $76,788 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10]
economic_impact: The goal of the pilot program is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [11] The cost of incarceration of just one person for three years is $277,035.10 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), meaning if the program helps keep just six women out of prison, the program will have already paid for itself. [10] [10] Establishing a permanent Women's Court in the First Circuit and a pilot program in the Third Circuit will help reduce recidivism by providing trauma‑informed, gender-responsive treatment programs for incarcerated women in the State. [12]
policy_impact: This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove its repeal date. [11] [11] It establishes a temporary three-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system. [11] The pilot program in the third circuit is set to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [11]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [11] The Committee has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts to facilitate further discussion on the measure. [12] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [11]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill establishes a temporary three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, which sunsets on June 30, 2028. [11] The measure appropriates unspecified sums for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027. [11] The Judiciary's testimony outlines a three-year budget for the pilot project at a total cost of just over $1.50 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) million. [10] The Judiciary's proposed budget is $514,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 2025-2026, $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 2026-2027, and $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 2027-2028. [10] [10] This budget includes annual costs for a Women's Mental Health Professional at $175,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), Womens Behavioral Health Beds at $100,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor at $85,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and a Peer Specialist at $80,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] [10] The Department of Health also requests an annual budget of $221,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) to support the Kona pilot program. [12] The bill makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will have ongoing fiscal implications. [11] The judiciary is required to submit annual reports on the pilot program through the regular session of 2028. [11]
operating_revenue_impact: The legislative documents do not indicate any impact on operating revenues. [11] The measure appropriates unspecified funds from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for program expenditures. [11] No revenue-generating components are described in the bill or accompanying testimony. [11]
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary's testimony includes a request for technology costs in the first year of the pilot program totaling $4,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] This request includes a computer workstation in the probation waiting area for $1,200 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a computer for the Kona Probation Supervisor for $1,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and a printer for the Kona Probation Supervisor for $1,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] These are anticipated to be one-time costs covered within the first year's appropriation for the pilot program. [10]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The bill makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, indicating ongoing fiscal responsibilities beyond the six-year period. [11] [11] Part III of the Act, which establishes the three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit, is repealed on June 30, 2028. [11] Any fiscal implications for the Third Circuit program after the pilot's sunset date will depend on future legislation based on the Judiciary's reports and recommendations. [11]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary update from the previous fiscal note is that the bill has been amended by the Committee on Ways and Means to change the specific appropriation amounts for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 to unspecified amounts.
